Lab 4: Building ER diagrams using an UML modeling tool This lab designs ER diagrams in UML notation. The AutoER auto-grading software on PrairieLearn is used to design and mark your UML diagrams. It is also valuable to learn how to use commercial UML design software such as [Astah](http://astah.net/editions). Note: Astah no longer has a free community version. answers.text:
To pass the exam, you need to ensure that you receive a combined grade of at least 50% on the midterm and final exams. Here are some steps to help you prepare:

1. **Attend Classes**: Make sure to attend every class and participate in discussions.
2. **Prepare**: Read class notes before each session to stay ahead.
3. **Complete Assignments**: Finish all lab assignments on time, as they help reinforce your understanding.
4. **Practice**: Do additional practice questions beyond what is covered in labs.
5. **Utilize Resources**: Use the online materials and any supplemental database textbooks for additional study.
6. **Stay Consistent**: Maintain a strong, continuous effort in your studies to grasp the material thoroughly.

By following these guidelines and putting in the necessary effort, you will improve your chances of passing the exam and the course overall.

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

To approach Level 14, consider these hints:

1. **Review Query Structure**: Ensure your joins and table aliases correctly represent the relationships between employees and their supervisors or managers.

2. **Understand EXCEPT Usage**: Clarify what you want to achieve with the EXCEPT clause. Are you trying to find employees that are not managers, or is there another intent?

3. **Column Consistency**: Make sure that the columns selected in both parts of the EXCEPT clause match in terms of naming and context.

By analyzing these aspects, you can work towards correcting your SQL query.

answers.text:
To update a table, you'll typically use the `UPDATE` statement. Here are some hints to guide you:

1. **Basic Syntax**: The general form of an `UPDATE` statement is:
   ```
   UPDATE tableName
   SET columnName1 = value1, columnName2 = value2, ...
   WHERE condition;
   ```

2. **Setting Values**: You can set specific columns to new values. Make sure to specify which records to update using the `WHERE` clause to avoid updating all rows.

3. **Multiple Updates**: You can update multiple columns in a single statement by separating them with commas.

4. **Testing**: Try out your `UPDATE` commands on a sample database or table to see the changes in action. 

5. **Integrity Constraints**: Ensure that your updates do not violate any integrity constraints defined on the table.

If you're looking to perform specific updates, refer back to the example actions provided in your context for more tailored guidance.

It seems like you're encountering an error related to adding a foreign key constraint. A common reason for this is that the referenced table does not have an index on the primary key or unique key that the foreign key is trying to reference. 

To resolve this, consider checking the following:

1. Ensure that the column in the 'Recipe' table that you are referencing with your foreign key is either a primary key or has a unique index.
2. If it is not indexed, you may need to create an index on that column in the 'Recipe' table before you can add the foreign key constraint.

Review the structure of your 'Recipe' table to confirm these details.

## Install Docker Desktop

[Install Docker Desktop](https://www.docker.com/products/docker-desktop/) that works on Windows, Mac, and Linux.

## Install SQuirreL SQL (Optional)

[SQuirreL SQL](https://squirrel-sql.sourceforge.io/) is a graphical SQL query software written in Java.

# Submission Guidelines for Assignments

### Assignment Submission Rules
All assignments will be collected and marked using Canvas unless otherwise noted.

### How to Electronically Submit Your Assignments
When electronically submitting multiple code files (> 5 files), please zip the directory before submitting.
Note that you can resubmit an assignment, and the new submission overwrites the old submission and receives a new timestamp.

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

## Lab Schedule

|  Lab  |  Date  |  Topic  |
|----|------|-------|

# Environment Setup

Some of the lab assignments require running a database on your computer. These database systems are run using Docker that supports virtual containers so that the software does not have to be directly installed on your computer.

## Install Docker Desktop

[Install Docker Desktop](https://www.docker.com/products/docker-desktop/) that works on Windows, Mac, and Linux.

## Install VSCode

Although you may use any text editor, the officially supported editor is [VSCode](https://code.visualstudio.com/Download).

## Install Java

If your computer does not have at least Java 17, install [the latest Java version](https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/downloads/).

## Install SQuirreL SQL (Optional)

[SQuirreL SQL](https://squirrel-sql.sourceforge.io/) is a graphical SQL query software written in Java. 

# Assignment Setup

For assignments that use Docker, a GitHub repository or zip file will be provided with starter code and Docker configuration information. The importa

To create a text file from Docker, you can follow these hints:

1. **Connect to the Container**: Use the command provided in the context to connect to your MySQL container.
2. **Run SQL Commands**: Once inside, you can execute SQL queries that might generate text output.
3. **Export Data**: If you want to create a CSV file from your database, use the `SELECT ... INTO OUTFILE` command in MySQL.

Remember to ensure that the path you specify has the correct permissions for writing files.

To save a text file in MySQL, consider these hints:

1. **Use the Correct Command**: You can use the `SELECT ... INTO OUTFILE` command to export data from a table into a text file.
2. **Specify File Path**: Ensure you provide a valid file path where MySQL has permission to write.
3. **File Format**: Decide on the format of your text file (e.g., CSV) and adjust the command accordingly.

If you need more specifics on the command syntax, feel free to ask!

# COSC 304 - Introduction to Database Systems
Lab 9 - Handling Data Formats (CSV, XML, JSON) Both paths do the [lab 9 assignment](../). There are no other requirements for this lab.

# COSC 304 - Introduction to Database Systems
Lab 3: Writing SQL Queries This lab practices writing SQL queries on a MySQL database. **Submit the lab answers on Canvas as a text file or document that contains all of your SQL commands or show a TA your SQL commands in a help session.** Practice questions are [available](practice). The [assignment](assign) uses MySQL and Docker and **requires computer setup by following these [setup instructions](../setup).**

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

answers.text:
To find pairs of books with different ISBNs but the same title, you'll want to use a SQL query that involves grouping and filtering. Consider using the `GROUP BY` clause on the title and then applying a condition to check for different ISBNs. 

Think about how you can structure your query to ensure that each pair is only listed once, perhaps by using a combination of conditions in your `HAVING` clause. What might you do with the results to filter out duplicate pairs?

# COSC 304 - Introduction to Database Systems
Lab 4: Building ER diagrams using an UML modeling tool This lab designs ER diagrams in UML notation. The AutoER auto-grading software on PrairieLearn is used to design and mark your UML diagrams. It is also valuable to learn how to use commercial UML design software such as [Astah](http://astah.net/editions). Note: Astah no longer has a free community version. Request a student license or use the 30-day trial. drawio is an online drawing tool that can also be used but it does not have as good support for database modeling in UML.

AutoER PrairieLearn link: https://plcanary.ok.ubc.ca/pl/course_instance/6/instructor/assessment/146/questions

Example #1

Think about attending classes, completing assignments, and utilizing all available resources to enhance your understanding.

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

answers.text: For many lab assignments, you can get bonus marks if you complete it before the Friday midnight deadline. Showing a TA in a help session before Monday at 4 p.m. is a 10% bonus and before Wednesday at 4 p.m. is a 5% bonus. The instructor may announce different dates and the bonus may not apply to all labs, so pay attention to class announcements. For example, September 30th is a holiday, so the deadline for a 10% bonus for lab 3 is Tuesday, October 1st. You must attend a help session and show a TA or instructor to get the bonus. The bonus does not apply for early submission on Canvas. This policy is in place to encourage interaction with the TAs/instructor, provide real-time feedback to help learning, and reduce procrastination to allow students to perform their best.

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

answers.text: For Lab 5, it's important to maintain consistency between your design and the SQL data types. If there's no `datetime` data type available in Astah, you could consider using `char` to represent dates, but be cautious about how you format them. Alternatively, you might want to check if you can use a similar data type, like `string` or `date`, if available. Remember, the goal is to accurately reflect the data types you'll use in SQL.

# COSC 304 - Introduction to Database Systems
Lab 6: Using Java/JDBC with MySQL and Microsoft SQL Server This assignment practices developing Java code that uses JDBC to connect to a MySQL database. The database is a standard order database consisting of products, customers, orders, ordered products, and employees. There is a list of products to order and a list of employees who take orders. An order has an id and date and may contain multiple products. The database schema is below: 
Customer (CustomerId, CustomerName)
Employee (EmployeeId, EmployeeName, Salary, SupervisorId)
Product(ProductId, ProductName, ListPrice)
Orders (OrderId, OrderDate, CustomerId, EmployeeId, Total)
OrderedProduct (OrderId, ProductId, Quantity, Price)
## Initial Steps Download the [starter code](304_lab6.zip) and unzip. The starter code has a SQL DDL script to create the database, a JUnit test program called `Te

rders. An Order has an auto-increment id, order date, and total order amount (e.g. $55.75). Also store the shipment address, city, state, country, and postal code. Use OrderSummary as entity/table name as Order is a keyword in SQL. - The store sells products. A Product has an auto-increment id, name, price, image URL (string), image (BLOB), and description. - A product has a category. A category has one or more Products. A Category has an auto-increment id and name. - Products are part of an order. An order may have multiple products. For each product in an order track the quantity and price. - An order is shipped with a shipment. A Shipment has an auto-increment id, a shipment date, and a description. A shipment contains only one order. - A Warehouse contains products. A product may be stored at multiple warehouses with different inventory values. A shipment will

d, Quantity, Price) ## Initial Steps Download the [starter code](304_lab6.zip) and unzip. The starter code has a SQL DDL script to create the database, a JUnit test program called `TestOrderJDBC.java`, and the code file to edit called `OrderJDBC.java`. It also contains the MySQL JDBC JAR file. Use VSCode to edit the code files. You will need to install the Java extension to compile and run. ## Question 1 (35 marks) Write the code to complete the methods in `OrderJDBC.java` (look for `TODO` items). **Your code will be graded based on it passing the JUnit tests.** You can show the TA all JUnit tests passing to receive full marks. Otherwise, submit your source code via Canvas.

List all customers in database (listAllCustomers) 3 marks
List all orders for a customer (listCustomerOrders) 3 marks

answers.text:
It seems like you're encountering a "No suitable driver found" error for your JDBC connection. Here are some hints to troubleshoot this issue:

1. **Driver Dependency**: Ensure that you have the SQL Server JDBC driver included in your project's dependencies. If you're using Maven or Gradle, check your build configuration for the correct driver.

2. **Driver Registration**: Sometimes, you need to explicitly register the driver in your code using `Class.forName("com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver")`.

3. **Correct URL Format**: Double-check your JDBC URL format for SQL Server. It should match the required syntax.

4. **Classpath**: Make sure the JDBC driver is in your project's classpath when running the application.

If you review these aspects, you should be able to resolve the issue.

answers.text:
It sounds like you're experiencing a login issue with Microsoft SQL Server. 

Here are some hints to help you troubleshoot:

1. **Check Configuration Files**: Ensure that your connection settings, including the user ID, are correctly specified in the configuration files. If you have a docker-compose file for your SQL Server, look for any environment variables that might define the user ID.

2. **Default Credentials**: If you're using a pre-configured SQL Server image, it often comes with default user IDs and passwords. Check the documentation or the repository from where you obtained the image for any default credentials.

3. **Connection String**: Review the connection string you're using. Make sure it’s formatted correctly and that any parameters are set properly.

4. **SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS)**: If you have access to SSMS or a similar tool, you might be able to connect using different methods to find the user ID.

5. **Logs**: Check the SQL Server logs for any additional information on the login attempts. This may provide more context or clues about the issue.

If you still can't find the user ID, consider reaching out to your instructor or lab supervisor for further assistance.

#### Allowed
- Collaboration in groups of up to 4 on Canvas quizzes and in-class exercises

#### Not Allowed
 - One person providing all answers for a quiz/exercise to a group of people of any size
 - Sharing, posting, or distributing answers to other students or websites for quizzes/exercises
 - Answering questions for another student or submitting answers on their behalf
 - Requesting help from previous students in the course or other individuals outside of the course
 - Relying on others to do work for me or not contributing reasonable effort to group activities
 - Dividing up the work for a quiz or exercise between members of an approved group (*Not Recommended*)

Customer (CustomerId, CustomerName)
Employee (EmployeeId, EmployeeName, Salary, SupervisorId)
Product(ProductId, ProductName, ListPrice)
Orders (OrderId, OrderDate, CustomerId, EmployeeId, Total)
OrderedProduct (OrderId, ProductId, Quantity, Price)

answers.text: Non-updatable views do still get automatically updated when their base tables are updated. The concept of "updatable views" specifically refers to the ability to perform updates directly on the view itself. Remember, views reflect the current state of the base tables, regardless of whether they are updatable or not.

### Triggers

Triggers are also called event-condition-action (ECA) rules. When an event occurs (such as inserting a tuple) that satisfies a given condition (any SQL boolean-valued expression) an action is performed (which is any sequence of SQL statements). Triggers provide a general way for detecting events and responding to them.

There are statement level triggers (execute once per statement) and row level triggers (execute once per row). Row level triggers use `FOR EACH ROW` clause. A trigger may fire `BEFORE`, `AFTER`, or `INSTEAD OF` and `INSERT`, `DELETE`, or `UPDATE` event.

Triggers can be created in [MySQL](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/create-trigger.html) and [SQL Server](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/t-sql/statements/create-trigger-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver16). The trigger syntax varies between database system

riting some XPath queries.

### JSON

**JavaScript Object Notation (JSON)** is a method for serializing data objects into text form. It is human-readable, supports semi-structured data, and has supporting libraries in many programming languages. It is often used for data interchange between a client and the server. 

#### JSON constructs
- **Values:** number, strings (double quoted), true, false, null
- **Objects:** enclosed in { } and consist of set of key-value pairs
- **Arrays:** enclosed in [ ] and are lists of values
- Objects and arrays can be nested.

An online JSON validator is [JSONLint](https://jsonlint.com).

### Views

A **view** is a named query.  Views may be either virtual or materialized in the database. Advantages of views include data independence, easier querying, improved performance for materialized views, and the ability to enforce security constraints using GRANT/REVOKE on views instead of base tables.

### Triggers

There are no make-up midterm exams. However, my course policy is
that if you do better on the final exam then that replaces your mark on one or both midterms. 

For example, if you got 70% on the midterm and 80% on the final, your midterm mark is changed to 80%. Even if your mark on the midterm was lower than you wanted, you still can improve that mark by doing well on the final.

Also, any bonus marks on labs, including if they result in over 100%, go to your overall grade. For example, if you get 22/20 for the assignment component, that extra 2% goes directly to your overall grade.

I am available to answer any questions you have and help you if you feel that your midterm did not reflect your abilities.

s, and so on. An invoice is displayed either in printed or Web-based form as a sequence of line items, with each line item consisting of a description and an amount, such as "Hotel Cafe $29.75". Note that the database does not keep track of, say, the costs of items on the restaurant's menu or the cost of renting each room at various times throughout the year; it is assumed that another software system provides this information to our database, since our system only handles reservations and billing.
  • When a guest pays his or her bill or a portion of his or her bill a line item is added to the invoice that indicates how much was paid, and in what form the payment was made (e.g. "Visa $-500.00", in the case of a $500 payment made using a Visa credit card).
  • At the bottom of each invoice is a total balance, which is the sum of the amounts in each of the line items, including both charges and payments. An invoice is considered paid if the amount is $0.00.

answers.text:
The JDBC URL for connecting to a MySQL database typically follows this format: 

`jdbc:mysql://server/database?user=username&password=password`

Here's how you can fill it in:

1. **server**: Replace this with the address of your MySQL server (e.g., `localhost` or a specific IP).
2. **database**: Replace this with the name of your database.
3. **username**: This should be your MySQL username.
4. **password**: This should be your MySQL password.

For example, if your server is `cosc304.ok.ubc.ca`, your database is `testDB`, your username is `test`, and your password is `yourpassword`, the URL would look like:

`jdbc:mysql://cosc304.ok.ubc.ca/testDB?user=test&password=yourpassword`

Make sure to adjust it according to your specific details!

# Submission Guidelines for Assignments

### Assignment Submission Rules
All assignments will be collected and marked using Canvas unless otherwise noted.

### How to Electronically Submit Your Assignments
When electronically submitting multiple code files (> 5 files), please zip the directory before submitting.
Note that you can resubmit an assignment, and the new submission overwrites the old submission and receives a new timestamp.

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

## Course Description
**Official Calendar:** Databases from a user's perspective: querying with SQL, designing with UML, and using programs to analyze data. Construction of database-driven applications and websites and experience with current database technologies.  Completion of COSC 121 is recommended.
**Prerequisite:** One of COSC 111, COSC 123, COSC 210. Third-ye

of database-driven applications and websites and experience with current database technologies.  Completion of COSC 121 is recommended.
**Prerequisite:** One of COSC 111, COSC 123, COSC 210. Third-year standing.

**Specific description:** This course provides an introduction to database systems including database querying, design, and programming. The course consists of three major components. The first component explains databases from a user perspective including how to query using SQL and relational algebra. The second component involves designing relational databases using Entity-Relationship (ER) diagrams and UML. The last component involves experiential learning on real-world use cases of databases for software development and data analytics. Technologies used include Java, JDBC, JSP, Python, and PHP. Students completing the course have experience with current database technologies, and the ability to use databases, analyze the contained data, and develop programs to automate

2. **Prepare in Advance**: Read class notes before each session to familiarize yourself with the topics.

5. **Utilize Resources**: Make use of online materials and supplemental textbooks to enhance your learning.
6. **Stay Consistent**: Put in a strong, continuous effort to keep up with readings and assignments.

With dedication and hard work, you can successfully grasp the material and excel in the course.

answers.text: A referential integrity constraint defines a foreign key that references the primary key of another table. If a foreign key contains a value that is not NULL, that value must exist in the referenced primary key relation. For example, in a table like "workson," the foreign keys "workson.eno" must reference "emp.eno," and "workson.pno" must reference "proj.pno." This ensures that relationships between tables remain consistent.

answers.text:
The error message indicates that the relational algebra syntax you are using is incorrect. Specifically, the "←" symbol is not recognized as valid syntax in relational algebra. 

In relational algebra, assignments are typically not represented using the "←" symbol. Instead, you should directly use expressions without any assignment operator. For example, instead of writing:

```
temp ← γ firstName, lastName, count(isbn)(BookAuthor)
```

You should directly use the aggregation in the following way:

```
result ← π firstName, lastName (σ count(isbn) > 1 (γ firstName, lastName, count(isbn)(BookAuthor)))
```

This keeps your operations in line with standard relational algebra conventions and avoids the syntax error you encountered.

answers.text:
Your relational algebra statement has a few issues:

1. **Aggregation and Selection Order**: You cannot directly apply a selection (σ) on the result of an aggregation (γ) based on an aggregated attribute like `count(isbn)`. The selection should be applied after the aggregation.

2. **Missing Temporary Relation**: You should first create a temporary relation for the aggregation result before applying the selection.

A corrected version could be:

1. Assign the aggregation to a temporary relation:
   ``` 
   temp ← γ firstName, lastName, count(isbn)(BookAuthor)
   ```

2. Then apply the selection:
   ```
   result ← π firstName, lastName (σ count(isbn) > 1 (temp))
   ```

This way, you first compute the counts and then filter based on that count.

answers.text:
Here's a simple brownie recipe:

**Ingredients:**
- 1/2 cup (115g) unsalted butter
- 1 cup (200g) granulated sugar
- 2 large eggs
- 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
- 1/3 cup (40g) unsweetened cocoa powder
- 1/2 cup (65g) all-purpose flour
- 1/4 teaspoon salt
- 1/4 teaspoon baking powder

**Instructions:**
1. Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C) and grease a 9x9-inch baking pan.
2. Melt the butter in a saucepan. Remove from heat and stir in sugar, eggs, and vanilla.
3. Beat in cocoa, flour, salt, and baking powder until well combined.
4. Spread the batter into the prepared pan.
5. Bake for 20-25 minutes. Do not overcook; the brownies should be soft in the center.
6. Let them cool before cutting into squares.

Enjoy your brownies!

answers.text:
To store the result of your join operation in a relation, you can use the `SELECT INTO` syntax in SQL. Based on your previous expression, you can structure it as follows:

```sql
SELECT Book.isbn
INTO result
FROM Book
JOIN Stock ON Book.isbn = Stock.isbn
WHERE Stock.storeName = 'All Books' OR Stock.storeName = 'Some Books';
```

This SQL statement will create a new table called `result` containing the ISBNs of the books from either 'All Books' or 'Some Books'. If you are looking for a specific implementation in relational algebra, you can define the result relation as:

```
result(res) ← π(Book.isbn) (Book ⨝ σ(storeName='All Books' or storeName='Some Books')(Stock))
```

This ensures that the result is stored correctly.

answers.text:
The expression `result(res) ← π(Book.isbn) (Book)` is syntactically correct in relational algebra, as it projects the `isbn` attribute from the `Book` relation and stores the result in a new relation called `res`. However, if it is not working, consider the following possibilities:

1. **Relation Name**: Ensure that the relation `Book` actually exists in your context and is correctly spelled.

2. **Attribute Name**: Verify that the attribute `isbn` exists within the `Book` relation.

3. **Environment/Implementation**: Check if your relational algebra implementation or environment supports the projection operation and creation of new relations properly.

If all these aspects are correct, the expression should work as intended.

answers.text:
To connect MySQL server to SQuirreL, follow these hints:

1. **Download and Install**: Make sure you have downloaded and installed SQuirreL SQL from the official site.

2. **JDBC Driver**: Ensure that you've downloaded the MySQL JDBC driver and placed it in the `lib` folder of SQuirreL.

3. **Create an Alias**: Set up an alias in SQuirreL to establish a connection to your MySQL server. This will involve specifying the connection details.

4. **Connection Details**: When creating the alias, ensure you input the correct JDBC URL format, server address, database name, and your user credentials.

5. **Test the Connection**: Once you’ve filled out the necessary information, test the connection to ensure everything is set up correctly.

If you follow these steps, you should be able to connect to your MySQL server. Let me know if you need further help!

answers.text:
"root@localhost" refers to the root user connecting to a MySQL database on the local machine. Here are a few hints to consider:

1. **User Privileges**: The "root" user typically has full administrative privileges on the database. Understanding user roles in MySQL is crucial.

2. **Connection Context**: "localhost" means that the connection is being made to a database instance running on the same machine as the client.

3. **Access Issues**: If you are encountering access denied errors, it may be related to incorrect passwords or insufficient privileges for the root user.

Exploring these points will help deepen your understanding of MySQL user connections!

# Submission Guidelines for Assignments

### Assignment Submission Rules
All assignments will be collected and marked using Canvas unless otherwise noted.

### How to Electronically Submit Your Assignments
When electronically submitting multiple code files (> 5 files), please zip the directory before submitting.
Note that you can resubmit an assignment, and the new submission overwrites the old submission and receives a new timestamp.

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

### Step #2: Access MySQL using Command Interface

MySQL commands can be running using the command line within the Docker container. Run the command:

```
docker exec -it cosc304-mysql bash
```

This will start a command line session. Connect to MySQL using:

```
mysql -u root -p
```
OR
```
mysql -u testuser -p
```

The password is given in the `docker-compose.yml` file (which you are **encouraged to change**). Note that all commands are terminated with a semi-colon (`;`). Some useful commands are:

| Use database `dbname`  | `use dbname;`  |
| List all tables  | `show tables;`  |

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

To force it to use double-quotes, run this command when you start a session: `set session sql_mode = 'ANSI';` It is also possible to set this globally using  `set global sql_mode = 'ANSI';` **Avoid using delimited identifiers for lab 2.**

in the `docker-compose.yml` file.
 - Your database is `mydb`. There are other databases also created such as `workson` and `university`.

## Step #2: Access MySQL using Command Interface

MySQL commands can be running using the command line within the Docker container. Run the command:

```
docker exec -it cosc304-mysql bash
```

This will start a command line session. Connect to MySQL using:

```
mysql -u root -p
```
OR
```
mysql -u testuser -p
```

The password is given in the `docker-compose.yml` file (which you are **encouraged to change**). Note that all commands are terminated with a semi-colon (`;`). Some useful commands are:

| Function  | Command |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Listing all databases	  | `show databases;`  |
| Use database `dbname`  | `use dbname;`  |
| List all tables  | `show tables;`  |

![Connecting using MySQL Command Line](img/commandline.png)

# Environment Setup

Some of the lab assignments require running a database on your computer. These database systems are run using Docker that supports virtual containers so that the software does not have to be directly installed on your computer.

## Install Docker Desktop

[Install Docker Desktop](https://www.docker.com/products/docker-desktop/) that works on Windows, Mac, and Linux.

## Install VSCode

Although you may use any text editor, the officially supported editor is [VSCode](https://code.visualstudio.com/Download).

## Install Java

If your computer does not have at least Java 17, install [the latest Java version](https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/downloads/).

## Install SQuirreL SQL (Optional)

[SQuirreL SQL](https://squirrel-sql.sourceforge.io/) is a graphical SQL query software written in Java.

To calculate the percentage from your Canvas quiz score, you can use the following formula:

\[ \text{Percentage} = \left( \frac{\text{Canvas quiz score}}{84} \right) \times 100 \]

This will give you the percentage score for your Canvas quizzes. Then, to find out how this contributes to your overall grade, use:

\[ \text{Overall Contribution} = \left( \frac{\text{Canvas quiz score}}{84} \right) \times 10 \]

Make sure to consider the total points available and how much you need to score to achieve your desired overall grade!

# Submission Guidelines for Assignments

### Assignment Submission Rules
All assignments will be collected and marked using Canvas unless otherwise noted.

### How to Electronically Submit Your Assignments
When electronically submitting multiple code files (> 5 files), please zip the directory before submitting.
Note that you can resubmit an assignment, and the new submission overwrites the old submission and receives a new timestamp.

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

answers.text:
To tackle this question, consider breaking it down into a few key steps:

1. **Aggregate Shipments**: Start by counting how many times each product has been shipped. You will likely want to use a `GROUP BY` clause on the `shippedproduct` table, along with a `JOIN` to connect it to the `product` table.

2. **Calculate Average Shipments**: Use a subquery to calculate the average number of shipments across all products. This will help you identify which products exceed the average.

3. **Filter and Order Results**: In your main query, filter the products based on the comparison with the average number of shipments. Finally, make sure to order the results by the number of shipments in descending order and by product ID in ascending order.

Keep these steps in mind as you construct your SQL query! If you need further clarification on any specific part, feel free to ask!

answers.text: No, you cannot use aggregation functions like `COUNT()` directly in the `WHERE` clause. Instead, aggregate functions should be used with the `HAVING` clause after grouping the results. To identify the entities in your databank, start by examining the provided relational schema. Look for the main nouns or concepts that represent the data. In your case, you might want to consider entities like "branch," "customer," and "deposit." Each of these represents a distinct category of information. 

Try to think about what attributes each entity would have based on the schema you have. Once you've identified the entities, you can focus on their relationships. If you need more specific guidance, let me know!

It seems like you're encountering an access denied error when trying to connect to the database. Here are some hints to troubleshoot the issue:

1. **Check Credentials**: Ensure that the username (`testuser`) and password you are using are correct.

2. **User Privileges**: Verify that the user has the necessary privileges to access the database. This may involve checking the database permissions for `testuser`.

3. **Host Configuration**: Check if the user is allowed to connect from the IP address `172.18.0.1`. Sometimes, users are restricted to connect only from specific hosts.

4. **Database URL**: Make sure that the JDBC URL is correctly formatted and points to the right database.

You can look into these areas to resolve the issue. If you have access to the database management system, you can run queries to check user permissions and connection settings.

# COSC 304 - Introduction to Database Systems
Lab 6: Using Java/JDBC with MySQL and Microsoft SQL Server This assignment practices developing Java code that uses JDBC to connect to a MySQL database. The database is a standard order database consisting of products, customers, orders, ordered products, and employees. There is a list of products to order and a list of employees who take orders. An order has an id and date and may contain multiple products. The database schema is below: 
Customer (CustomerId, CustomerName)
Employee (EmployeeId, EmployeeName, Salary, SupervisorId)
Product(ProductId, ProductName, ListPrice)
Orders (OrderId, OrderDate, CustomerId, EmployeeId, Total)
OrderedProduct (OrderId, ProductId, Quantity, Price)

10 bonus marks can be received by going beyond the basic assignment requirements:

- **+5 marks** - for allowing a user to remove items from their shopping cart and to change the quantity of items ordered when viewing their cart.
- **+5 marks** - for validating a customer's password when they try to place an order.
- **Up to +5 marks** - for improving the looks of the site such as:
	- **+2 marks** - for a page header with links to product page, list order, and shopping cart
	- **+3 marks** - for formatting product listing page to include better formatting as well as filter by category	
	- **+3 marks** - for improved formatting of cart page		

- Other bonus marks may be possible if discussed with the TA/instructor.

answers.text:
**Midterm #2 is in class on Tuesday, November 5th at 9:30 a.m. Make sure to have your student id. If you do not have a computer, please contact the professor before the exam so arrangements can be made.**

Midterm #2 includes notes on database design, ER modeling, ER-to-relational mapping, and database programming in Java and Python. 

Here is the format:
- 5 marks for 5 multiple choice
- 5 marks for ER design question (on PrairieLearn). Upload an image with your answer. 
- 5 marks for converting ER model to relational model. Make sure to identify primary and foreign keys.
- 10 marks for a database programming question. You may use either Java or Python.
Note: There is nothing on web programming or R on the midterm.
**Total marks: 25**
**Time limit: 80 minutes**

Midterm exam rules:
- Students may use resources provided in the course including notes, labs, and other materials posted on GitHub and Canvas.
- Students may use a programming environment for Python or Java.
- Students **may NOT use** any external resources on the Internet (e.g. Stack Overflow) or communicate with any other people during the exam. Google docs, ChatGPT, and other cloud and AI software are not allowed. **Use will result in automatic zero.**
- **Only one device allowed. No secondary devices besides laptop.**

There is a [practice exam on Canvas](https://canvas.ubc.ca/courses/150492/quizzes/790014).

# Submission Guidelines for Assignments

### Assignment Submission Rules
All assignments will be collected and marked using Canvas unless otherwise noted.

### How to Electronically Submit Your Assignments
When electronically submitting multiple code files (> 5 files), please zip the directory before submitting.
Note that you can resubmit an assignment, and the new submission overwrites the old submission and receives a new timestamp.

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

## Lab Schedule

gnment and explain what you did to deserve the extra marks.  An [example web site with improved features is available](http://cosc304.ok.ubc.ca/rlawrenc/tomcat/Lab7/bonus/shop.html).**

#### Deliverables:

1. Option #1: Demonstrate your working site to the TA in a help session. Bonus marks if completed by early deadlines. No submission on Canvas is required.
2. Option #2: Submit in a single zip file all your source code using Canvas. This can be done by exporting your project. Submit all your files, but the files you must change are: `listprod.js`, `listorder.js` and `order.js`.
3. Only one submission for a group. Put both partners' names and student numbers on the submission.

# COSC 304 - Introduction to Database Systems
Lab 4: Building ER diagrams using an UML modeling tool This lab designs ER diagrams in UML notation. The AutoER auto-grading software on PrairieLearn is used to design and mark your UML diagrams. It is also valuable to learn how to use commercial UML design software such as [Astah](http://astah.net/editions). Note: Astah no longer has a free community version. Request a student license or use the 30-day trial. drawio is an online drawing tool that can also be used but it does not have as good support for database modeling in UML.

AutoER PrairieLearn link: https://plcanary.ok.ubc.ca/pl/course_instance/6/assessment/145

answers.text:
There are no make-up midterm exams. However, my course policy is
that if you do better on the final exam then that replaces your mark on one or both midterms. 

For example, if you got 70% on the midterm and 80% on the final, your midterm mark is changed to 80%. Even if your mark on the midterm was lower than you wanted, you still can improve that mark by doing well on the final.

Also, any bonus marks on labs, including if they result in over 100%, go to your overall grade. For example, if you get 22/20 for the assignment component, that extra 2% goes directly to your overall grade.

I am available to answer any questions you have and help you if you feel that your midterm did not reflect your abilities.

# COSC 304 - Introduction to Database Systems
Lab 4: Building ER diagrams using an UML modeling tool This lab designs ER diagrams in UML notation. The AutoER auto-grading software on PrairieLearn is used to design and mark your UML diagrams. It is also valuable to learn how to use commercial UML design software such as [Astah](http://astah.net/editions). Note: Astah no longer has a free community version. Request a student license or use the 30-day trial. drawio is an online drawing tool that can also be used but it does not have as good support for database modeling in UML.

AutoER PrairieLearn link: https://plcanary.ok.ubc.ca/pl/course_instance/6/assessment/145

If using SQuirreL, the JDBC URL is: `jdbc:sqlserver://cosc304.ok.ubc.ca;databaseName=analysis;trustServerCertificate=true`.  User id and password are on Canvas. answers.text:
There are no make-up midterm exams. However, my course policy is
that if you do better on the final exam then that replaces your mark on one or both midterms. 

For example, if you got 70% on the midterm and 80% on the final, your midterm mark is changed to 80%. Even if your mark on the midterm was lower than you wanted, you still can improve that mark by doing well on the final.

Also, any bonus marks on labs, including if they result in over 100%, go to your overall grade. For example, if you get 22/20 for the assignment component, that extra 2% goes directly to your overall grade.

I am available to answer any questions you have and help you if you feel that your midterm did not reflect your abilities.

A make-up exam may have a question format different from the regular exam. There will be no make-up midterm exams.  If the reason for absence is satisfactory, the student’s final exam will be worth more of the final grade.  Further information on Academic Concession is in the Academic Calendar http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/okanagan/index.cfm?tree=3,48,0,0.

It seems like you are encountering an issue with your project setup. Here are some hints to resolve the "not on its project's build path" error:

1. **Check Project Configuration**: Ensure that your project is correctly set up in your IDE. Look for any settings related to build paths or project libraries.

2. **Include Required Libraries**: Make sure that all necessary libraries and dependencies for your project are included in the build path.

3. **Refresh Project**: Sometimes, simply refreshing the project can resolve path issues. Try cleaning and rebuilding your project.

4. **Look at Project Structure**: Verify that the main method is correctly defined and that the file is located in the appropriate source folder.

5. **Consult Documentation**: If you're still having trouble, refer to the course materials or online resources for specific instructions related to your IDE or project setup.

Good luck, and let me know if you need further guidance!

sociated with each user as well as a password. The authorization identifier is used to determine which database objects the user has access to.

Privileges give users the right to perform operations on database objects.  Some example privileges:
- `SELECT` - the user can retrieve data from table
- `INSERT` - the user can insert data into table
- `UPDATE` - the user can modify data in the table
- `DELETE` - the user can delete data (rows) from the table

The `GRANT` command gives privileges on database objects to users.

```
GRANT {privilegeList | ALL [PRIVILEGES]}
  ON ObjectName
  TO {AuthorizationIdList | PUBLIC}
  [WITH GRANT OPTION]
```
The `REVOKE` command is used to remove privileges on database objects from users.

```
REVOKE [GRANT OPTION FOR]{privilegeList | ALL [PRIVILEGES]}
  ON ObjectName
  FROM {AuthorizationIdList | PUBLIC} {RESTRICT|CASCADE}
```

## Step #2: Access MySQL using Command Interface

MySQL commands can be running using the command line within the Docker container. Run the command:

```
docker exec -it cosc304-mysql bash
```

This will start a command line session. Connect to MySQL using:

```
mysql -u root -p
```
OR
```
mysql -u testuser -p
```

The password is given in the `docker-compose.yml` file (which you are **encouraged to change**). Note that all commands are terminated with a semi-colon (`;`). Some useful commands are:

| Function  | Command |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Listing all databases	  | `show databases;`  |
| Use database `dbname`  | `use dbname;`  |
| List all tables  | `show tables;`  |

It sounds like there may be an issue with your permissions or the Docker setup. Here are a few hints to troubleshoot the problem:

1. **Check Docker Installation**: Ensure that Docker Desktop is properly installed and running.

2. **Verify Docker Compose File**: Look for any syntax errors or misconfigurations in your `docker-compose.yml` file.

3. **Run with Sufficient Privileges**: Make sure you are executing the command with sufficient permissions. You might need to try running your terminal or command prompt as an administrator.

4. **Check for Existing Containers**: There could be a conflict with existing containers. Use `docker ps -a` to see if there are any running or stopped containers that could be causing issues.

Try these steps and see if they help resolve the access denied issue!

Lab 8 ## [Development Stream](develop/) - Images, Security, and Transactions Add images and more features to your online store. ## [Analysis](analyze/) Stream - Data Prediction, Forecasting, and Visualization Extend the analysis to perform forecasting and prediction. Add improved visualizations and charts. ## Reference Material ### Images Images can be stored in the database, on the web server file system, or on a cloud service like Amazon S3. Typically, storing on the web server provides higher performance, but the images may not be as easy to secure compared to storing them in the database. ### Security Security in SQL is based on authorization identifiers, ownership, and privileges. An authorization identifier (or user id) is associated with each user as well as a password. The authorization identifier is used to determine which database objects the user has access to. Privileges give users the right to perform operations o

# COSC 304 - Introduction to Database Systems
Lab 7 ## Development Stream - Building a Database-enabled Web Site using JSP/PHP/Node Build an online store with a database and web interface. Three choices for language: [Java](java/), [PHP](php/), [Node.js](nodejs/). **SQL Server is not supported on the Apple M1 chip.** However, there is an alternate version that is. In the `docker-compose.yml` file, change: `image: mcr.microsoft.com/mssql/server:2019-latest` to this: `image: mcr.microsoft.com/azure-sql-edge` . ## [Analysis](analyze/) Stream - Using Databases with Analysis Software (Excel) Perform reporting on a company database using Excel for [analysis and visualization](analyze/).

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

answers.text:
There are no make-up midterm exams. However, my course policy is
that if you do better on the final exam then that replaces your mark on one or both midterms. 

For example, if you got 70% on the midterm and 80% on the final, your midterm mark is changed to 80%. Even if your mark on the midterm was lower than you wanted, you still can improve that mark by doing well on the final.

Also, any bonus marks on labs, including if they result in over 100%, go to your overall grade. For example, if you get 22/20 for the assignment component, that extra 2% goes directly to your overall grade.

I am available to answer any questions you have and help you if you feel that your midterm did not reflect your abilities.

## Step #2: Access MySQL using Command Interface

MySQL commands can be running using the command line within the Docker container. Run the command:

```
docker exec -it cosc304-mysql bash
```

This will start a command line session. Connect to MySQL using:

```
mysql -u root -p
```
OR
```
mysql -u testuser -p
```

The password is given in the `docker-compose.yml` file (which you are **encouraged to change**). Note that all commands are terminated with a semi-colon (`;`). Some useful commands are:

| Function  | Command |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Listing all databases	  | `show databases;`  |
| Use database `dbname`  | `use dbname;`  |
| List all tables  | `show tables;`  |

## Databases and Autonumber Fields

This database storing customers, orders, and products uses autonumber fields to assign a primary key value for orders.  An autonumber field is an integer field which is automatically assigned by the database.  The value of the counter starts at 1.  When a record is added, the value of the autonumber field for the new record is set to the counter and then the counter is incremented.  Thus, the values of the autonumber field for records are 1,2,3,...  Autonumber fields are useful as primary keys as they are guaranteed to be unique.  To create an autonumb

answers.text: Matrix algebra and relational algebra share some similarities, but they are distinct concepts. If you're looking to understand matrix algebra, consider focusing on operations like addition, multiplication, and finding determinants or inverses. For relational algebra, remember the operators like selection, projection, and join. If you have specific questions about matrix algebra, I can help guide you on those topics!

All assignments will be collected and marked using Canvas unless otherwise noted.

### How to Electronically Submit Your Assignments
When electronically submitting multiple code files (> 5 files), please zip the directory before submitting.

answers.text:
If Docker is starting forever, it might indicate an issue with the container configuration or resource allocation. Here are some hints to troubleshoot:

1. **Check Docker Desktop:** Ensure that Docker Desktop is running correctly without any errors.
2. **Inspect Logs:** Use `docker-compose logs` to see if there are any error messages in the logs that can help identify the problem.
3. **Resource Allocation:** Verify that your machine has enough resources allocated to Docker (CPU, memory).
4. **Docker Compose File:** Double-check your `docker-compose.yml` file for any misconfigurations.

By following these hints, you may identify the cause of the issue.

## Missing an Exam
Only students who miss the final exam for a reason that corresponds to the University of British Columbia Okanagan's policy on excused absences from examinations will be permitted to take the final exam at a later time. A make-up exam may have a question format different from the regular exam. There will be no make-up midterm exams.  If the reason for absence is satisfactory, the student’s final exam will be worth more of the final grade. answers.text:
There are no make-up midterm exams. However, my course policy is
that if you do better on the final exam then that replaces your mark on one or both midterms. 

For example, if you got 70% on the midterm and 80% on the final, your midterm mark is changed to 80%. Even if your mark on the midterm was lower than you wanted, you still can improve that mark by doing well on the final.

Also, any bonus marks on labs, including if they result in over 100%, go to your overall grade. For example, if you get 22/20 for the assignment component, that extra 2% goes directly to your overall grade.

I am available to answer any questions you have and help you if you feel that your midterm did not reflect your abilities.

riting some XPath queries.

### JSON

**JavaScript Object Notation (JSON)** is a method for serializing data objects into text form. It is human-readable, supports semi-structured data, and has supporting libraries in many programming languages. It is often used for data interchange between a client and the server. 

#### JSON constructs
- **Values:** number, strings (double quoted), true, false, null
- **Objects:** enclosed in { } and consist of set of key-value pairs
- **Arrays:** enclosed in [ ] and are lists of values
- Objects and arrays can be nested.

An online JSON validator is [JSONLint](https://jsonlint.com).

### Views

A **view** is a named query.  Views may be either virtual or materialized in the database. Advantages of views include data independence, easier querying, improved performance for materialized views, and the ability to enforce security constraints using GRANT/REVOKE on views instead of base tables.

### Triggers

Triggers are also called event-condition-actio

# COSC 304 - Introduction to Database Systems
Lab 7 - Using Databases with Analysis Software (Excel) You have just been hired as the first data analyst at the ACME company. ACME has been selling products for many years and recording that information in a database. However, they have not been using that collected data to improve their business by tracking key customers and item sales volume, and modifying their pricing and distribution strategies. Your role is to provide these insights to management in a way that is easily understood. ## ACME Company Details The ACME company sells all kinds of products. Every product has a given category, and customers are encouraged to review products. Customers place orders through a website. Orders are shipped from one of three warehouses in Kelowna, Winnipeg, and Toronto. Each warehouse maintains inventory on its products. The company needs information on its top selling products, largest customers, and efficiency of its distribution system.

## Question #1 - Stock Market Database (10 marks) Construct a database design in UML for a stock market tracking database. **Data types are not needed.** - The database tracks companies, where a `company` has a `name` and is identified by its `ticker symbol`. - Each company participates in a particular `industry`. An `industry` has an identifying `name` and also a `description`. - Stock market `analysts` cover stocks and produce `recommendations`. `Analysts` are distinguished from each other by the name of their `firm` and their `name`. Analysts also have an `accuracy rating` that measures the accuracy of their `recommendations`. - Each `recommendation` is from a particular `analyst` on a certain `company`. A `recommendation` includes a predicted `price` in the next 12 months and a `rating` for the stock (buy, hold, sell). - The database includes a `daily summary` for each company w

a certain `company`. A `recommendation` includes a predicted `price` in the next 12 months and a `rating` for the stock (buy, hold, sell).

- The database includes a `daily summary` for each company with a `closing price`, `volume`, `low price`, and `high price`. Daily summaries are identified by the company it is associated with and the `summary date`.

- `News events`are tracked for companies. A `news event` has an identifying `eventId` and has additional details on the event `text` and the `release date`. A `news event` may be associated with multiple companies, and a company may have many news events.

- A `course` is identified by its `course number` and has a `course name` and `year`.

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

There are no make-up midterm exams. However, my course policy is
that if you do better on the final exam then that replaces your mark on one or both midterms. 

For example, if you got 70% on the midterm and 80% on the final, your midterm mark is changed to 80%. Even if your mark on the midterm was lower than you wanted, you still can improve that mark by doing well on the final.

Also, any bonus marks on labs, including if they result in over 100%, go to your overall grade. For example, if you get 22/20 for the assignment component, that extra 2% goes directly to your overall grade.

I am available to answer any questions you have and help you if you feel that your midterm did not reflect your abilities.

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

answers.text:
To delete a row in your MySQL table, you can use the DELETE statement followed by a WHERE clause to specify the condition for deletion. If you want to delete a specific row, make sure to identify it correctly. Remember, if you use DELETE without a WHERE clause, it will remove all rows. 

If you're looking to delete a specific row based on a condition, think about how you can use the conditions mentioned in the context, such as `num = 1` or `message > 'C'`. 

For the second question, consider each statement and think about how DELETE operates in SQL to determine which ones are true. 

For the required privileges, reflect on what permissions are typically needed to perform DELETE operations in a database. 

If you have specific queries or need further hints, feel free to ask!

### Insert (5 marks)

Insert the following records into the appropriate tables.

#### Author

```
(1,'Joe Smith')
(2,'Fred Funk')
```

#### Ingredient
```
('BUTTR','Butter')
('FLOUR','Flour')
('MILK','Milk')
('EGGS','Eggs')
('SUGAR','Sugar')
```

#### Recipe
```
(100,'Cookies',1,'Mix butter, flour, milk, eggs, and sugar. Then hope for the best.')
(200,'Bread',2,'Knead flour with milk and eggs. Bake at 450F or until brown.')
```

#### Requires
You figure it out based on both recipes (choose your own amount).

#### Cook
Recipe for bread was made on September 15, 2024 (no comment). 
Recipe for cookies was made on September 23rd, 2024 at 1:35:45 p.m. Comment: 'It actually worked!'

### Update (2 marks)

2. Increase the amount of all required ingredients used with recipe 100 by 2.

**Live Classroom Schedule:** 11:00 a.m. to 12:30 p.m Tuesday/Thursday
**Mode of Delivery:** FIP 204 and live-stream on Zoom
**Office Hours:** Thursdays 2 to 4 p.m. (in-person and online)
**Office Location:** ASC 349
**Calendar Course Description from the UBCO Calendar:** [http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/okanagan/courses.cfm?go=name&code=COSC](https://okanagan.calendar.ubc.ca/course-descriptions/subject/cosc) ## Virtual Drop-in Session Hours | Day/Time | TA/Instructor | |----------|----------------| | Monday 9 to 11 a.m. | Eranga Desaa  /  Omar Abdelaziz | | Monday 2 to 4 p.m. | Justin Schoenit / Kevin Wang | | Tuesday 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. (class time) | Justin Schoenit | | Tuesday 2 to 4 p.m. | Eranga Desaa  /  Omar Abdelaziz | | Wednesday 2 to 4 p.m. | Eranga Desaa  /  Omar Abdelaziz | | Thursday 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.

User id: **your student number**  Password: **your student number**

PrairieLearn online system (Connect with your CWL): https://plcanary.ok.ubc.ca/

## Course Description
**Official Calendar:** Databases from a user's perspective: querying with SQL, designing with UML, and using programs to analyze data. Construction of database-driven applications and websites and experience with current database technologies.  Completion of COSC 121 is recommended.
**Prerequisite:** One of COSC 111, COSC 123, COSC 210. Third-ye

of database-driven applications and websites and experience with current database technologies.  Completion of COSC 121 is recommended.
**Prerequisite:** One of COSC 111, COSC 123, COSC 210. Third-year standing.

**Specific description:** This course provides an introduction to database systems including database querying, design, and programming. The course consists of three major components. The first component explains databases from a user perspective including how to query using SQL and relational algebra. The second component involves designing relational databases using Entity-Relationship (ER) diagrams and UML. The last component involves experiential learning on real-world use cases of databases for software development and data analytics. Technologies used include Java, JDBC, JSP, Python, and PHP. Students completing the course have experience with current database technologies, and the ability to use databases, analyze the contained data, and develop programs to automate

JSP, Python, and PHP. Students completing the course have experience with current database technologies, and the ability to use databases, analyze the contained data, and develop programs to automate data analysis and presentation.

## Course Objectives
**Course Format:** Interactive classes consist of topic introduction, understanding evaluation using quick questions, and concept mastery with larger exercises.  Practical skills and applications of topics are covered in assignments as well as practice using industrial database systems and software.

**Learning Outcomes:**
 - Describe how databases provide data abstraction and simplify writing programs to store and manipulate data.
 - Create relational algebra queries on relational databases using selection, projection, join, and set operators.
 - Construct SQL CREATE TABLE, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, and SELECT statements including queries with multiple joins, aggregation, grouping, and subqueries. Explain the translation of a SQL

operators.
 - Construct SQL CREATE TABLE, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, and SELECT statements including queries with multiple joins, aggregation, grouping, and subqueries. Explain the translation of a SQL query into relational algebra operators.
 - Analyze and understand existing database designs, design new databases using ER/UML modeling, and convert designs to the relational model including proper modeling of primary and foreign keys.
 - Develop programs and web sites that access a database to read data, perform analysis, and display output.
 - Perform data analysis, reporting, and visualization using data extracted from databases.
 - Use JSON and XML for data exchange and representation.
 - Execute and deploy databases on a computer using virtualization/containerization technology such as Docker.
 - Implement database security using user accounts/passwords and SQL privileges using GRANT and REVOKE.

## Missing an Exam
Only students who miss the final exam for a reason that corresponds to the University of British Columbia Okanagan's policy on excused absences from examinations will be permitted to take the final exam at a later time. A make-up exam may have a question format different from the regular exam. There will be no make-up midterm exams.  If the reason for absence is satisfactory, the student’s final exam will be worth more of the final grade. ## Your Responsibilities
Your responsibilities to this class and to your education as a whole include attendance and participation. You have a
responsibility to help create a classroom environment where all may learn. At the most basic level, this means you will
respect the other members of the class and the instructor and treat them with the courtesy you hope to receive in return.
Inappropriate classroom behavior may include: disruption of the classroom atmosphere, engaging in non-class activities,
talking on a cell-phone, inappropriate use of profanity in classroom discussion, use of abusive or disrespectful language
toward the instructor, a student in the class, or about other individuals or groups.

## Academic Integrity
The academic enterprise is founded on honesty, civility, and integrity.  As members of this enterprise, all students are expected to know, understand, and follow the codes of conduct regarding academic integrity.  At the most basic level, this means s

lity, and integrity.  As members of this enterprise, all students are expected to know, understand, and follow the codes of conduct regarding academic integrity.  At the most basic level, this means submitting only original work done by you and acknowledging all sources of information or ideas and attributing them to others as required.  This also means you should not cheat, copy, or mislead others about what is your work.  Violations of academic integrity (i.e., misconduct) lead to the breakdown of the academic enterprise, and therefore serious consequences arise and harsh sanctions are imposed.  For example, incidences of plagiarism or cheating may result in a mark of zero on the assignment or exam and more serious consequences may apply if the matter is referred to the President’s Advisory Committee on Student Discipline.  Careful records are kept in order to monitor and prevent recurrences. A more detailed description of academic integrity, including the policies and procedures, ma

ory Committee on Student Discipline.  Careful records are kept in order to monitor and prevent recurrences. A more detailed description of academic integrity, including the policies and procedures, may be found: http://okanagan.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=3,54,111,0  If you have any questions about how academic integrity applies to this course, please consult with your professor.

**The use of artificial intelligence (AI) assistance, such as ChatGPT or GitHub Copilot, for any assessed portions of this course is not permitted unless explicitly specified by the instructor.**

## Academic Integrity Course Policies
Academic integrity is critical to being a professional developer and a respected person. This is a guide to what is and is not acceptable behaviors in this course.

### In-Class Participation and Quizzes and Teamwork Collaboration
#### Allowed
- Collaboration in groups of up to 4 on Canvas quizzes and in-class exercises

#### Not Allowed
 - One person pro

### In-Class Participation and Quizzes and Teamwork Collaboration
#### Allowed
- Collaboration in groups of up to 4 on Canvas quizzes and in-class exercises

#### Not Allowed
 - One person providing all answers for a quiz/exercise to a group of people of any size
 - Sharing, posting, or distributing answers to other students or websites for quizzes/exercises
 - Answering questions for another student or submitting answers on their behalf
 - Requesting help from previous students in the course or other individuals outside of the course
 - Relying on others to do work for me or not contributing reasonable effort to group activities
 - Dividing up the work for a quiz or exercise between members of an approved group (*Not Recommended*)

### Assignments
#### Allowed
- Collaborating with your approved group members (usually two) and submitting a shared answer to the assignment
- Request help from the TA or instructor and use the answer/code that they provide
- Answer gener

ting with your approved group members (usually two) and submitting a shared answer to the assignment
- Request help from the TA or instructor and use the answer/code that they provide
- Answer general questions about assignments in chat or discussion forums (*Allowed with care*)

#### Not Allowed
 - Working on an individual assignment with a group of people and submitting minor variations of work developed together
 - For group assignment, completing all work independently and providing answer to rest of group
 - Sharing solutions to assignments with other students or on the Internet	
 - Receiving solutions to assignments from other sources (students, web, tutors, AI)

material including assignments, notes, and quizzes. No online/AI resources. No use of Google Docs. No secondary devices.

# Lab Assignments

All lab assignments are done on your time with assistance from teaching assistants and the instructor during help session hours. The best part of the course is developing with databases in the assignments. Please follow the submission guidelines.

**All assignments must be done in groups of two people.** No collaboration outside a group is allowed. The group must be setup on Canvas and only one submission per group is accepted.

**Many assignments use Docker to run databases on your computer. Follow the [setup instructions](setup) to get started.**

**Bonus for early submission: 10% bonus for certain labs if show answer to instructor/TA before Monday 4 p.m. the week assignment is due. 5% bonus if show answer to instructor/TA before Wednesday 4 p.m.**

Lab 1: Querying using Relational Algebra ## [RelaX - Online Relational Algebra Tool](https://dbis-uibk.github.io/relax/) [RelaX](https://dbis-uibk.github.io/relax/) is an online relational algebra tool that we will use for the assignments. It allows entering relational algebra expressions and executing them to get results. The data set can be loaded from a GitHub Gist including the [Bookstore data set (GIST: 367f41bb51110ef3c84bb5f906f2fb87)](https://gist.github.com/rlawrenc/367f41bb51110ef3c84bb5f906f2fb87) used for sample relational algebra queries in this lab. ## Relational Algebra Practice **These are practice questions that are not graded.** The lab practices writing queries in relational algebra using a [book database schema (GIST: 367f41bb51110ef3c84bb5f906f2fb87)](https://gist.github.com/rlawrenc/367f41bb51110ef3c84bb5f906f2fb87): 
Book (isbn, pubDate, listPrice, publisher, title, copyright)
Author (

schema (GIST: 367f41bb51110ef3c84bb5f906f2fb87)](https://gist.github.com/rlawrenc/367f41bb51110ef3c84bb5f906f2fb87): 
Book (isbn, pubDate, listPrice, publisher, title, copyright)
Author (firstName, lastName, address)
BookAuthor (isbn, firstName, lastName)
Bookstore (name, address)
Stock (storeName, isbn, storePrice, quantity)
The Author relation gives the author's first and last names and address. Each first name/last name pair is unique. The Book relation gives the isbn, title, copyright date, publication date, and recommended list price. Since a book can have multiple authors, the relation BookAuthor matches up authors (identified by name) with books (identified by ISBN). The Bookstore relation gives the name (key) and address of a book store. The Stock relation gives the bookstore name, the price, and the ISBN number of the book. listPrice and storePrice are re

kstore relation gives the name (key) and address of a book store. The Stock relation gives the bookstore name, the price, and the ISBN number of the book. listPrice and storePrice are real numbers. copyright and pubDate are integers (representing the year). All other attributes are strings. ### Questions: (Write the answer in relational algebra)
